issues.description: The problem statement and UML refer to a class named Stock (with methods add, take, findStockIngredient, addToStockIngredients, emptyStock) and show SealSaloon holding a Stock. However, the provided template (and the solution) implement this functionality in a class named Inventory (Inventory.java) while Stock.java is empty. SealSaloon in the solution uses an Inventory-typed static field. This class-name/type mismatch between the specification (Stock) and the template/solution (Inventory) is structural: students reading the problem will expect to find/modify Stock, but the working implementation is in Inventory, which can cause confusion about where to implement or modify stock-related behavior and which type to reference in SealSaloon.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the class name and usages consistent across the problem statement, template, and solution. Either:
- Rename Inventory (Inventory.java) to Stock (move/duplicate its implementation into Stock.java and remove or deprecate Inventory), and update all references (UML and text remain unchanged); or
- Update the problem statement and UML to refer to Inventory instead of Stock so the specification matches the template and solution. 
Either approach resolves student confusion by ensuring a single canonical class name for the stock/inventory functionality and aligning the type used in SealSaloon with the template code.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML refer to the central stock class as "Stock" (including method signatures like add, take, findStockIngredient, addToStockIngredients, emptyStock and explicit instructions that the saloon has a final Stock stock). The template and solution repositories instead provide this functionality in a class named Inventory (Inventory.java) and the SealSaloon implementation uses Inventory as the type of the shared stock. An empty Stock.java file is present in the repositories, increasing the risk of confusion. This naming mismatch (Stock vs Inventory) makes it harder for students to map the problem description / UML to the provided code and to the expected solution: students may look for a Stock class with the described methods and either fail to find it or be uncertain whether Inventory is the intended implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the name for the central stock concept consistent across artifacts. Either (A) rename the Inventory class/file to Stock (Inventory.java -> Stock.java and update references) so the code matches the problem statement/UML, or (B) update the problem statement/UML to refer to Inventory instead of Stock. Also remove or populate the empty Stock.java file in the repositories to avoid ambiguity. This alignment preserves the intended functionality while reducing mapping confusion for students.
